question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

In 1950, 400,000 lions [[☃ definition 6]] Africa. Today, fewer than 40,000 are left. Why? There are a few reasons. Humans have taken over most of the lands where lions used to live. Hunters kill lions for their fur. And [[☃ definition 5]] farmers hoping to keep their [[☃ definition 7]] safe also hunt lions.

When scientist Leela Hazzah moved to Kenya, she spoke to many Maasai, who felt frustrated that they were often left out of local [[☃ definition 4]] programs. Those conversations inspired an idea: What if Maasai warriors were hired to protect lions? Soon after, Hazzah created Lion Guardians. The group uses [[☃ definition 3]] and Maasai [[☃ definition 2]] to find and protect lions in the area. Today, 40 Lion Guardians protect more than 100 lions from [[☃ definition 1]] hunting. 

**Based on the information in the text, what are *two* reasons why there are so few lions today?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

[[☃ explanation 1]]

choices.clue:
This isn’t a reason mentioned in the text. The text says, “Hunters kill lions for their *fur,*” not their teeth and claws.

**Top tip!** We can forget information only seconds after we read it. Go back to check the text for answers!
choices.content: Hunters illegally kill lions for their teeth and claws.

choices.clue: **This is one of the best choices.** The text says that “Maasai farmers hoping to keep their livestock safe also hunt lions.” So one of the reasons why there are so few lions today is because farmers hunt them to keep their animals safe.
choices.content: Farmers hunt lions to protect their animals.

choices.clue: This isn’t a reason why there are so few lions today. The text tells us that the Lion Guardians “protect lions.” Protecting lions wouldn’t make it so that there were fewer lions.
choices.content: The Lion Guardians use technology and traditional Maasai tracking techniques.

choices.clue: **This is one of the best choices.** The text says, “There are a few reasons” why there are fewer lions than there used to be. It then explains, “Humans have taken over most of the lands where lions used to live.” So there aren’t many lions today because they don’t have much space left to live in.
choices.content: Humans have taken over many areas where lions used to live.

choices.clue: This isn’t a reason why there are so few lions today. This tells us that there *are* fewer lions than there used to be, but it doesn’t give a reason *why* that is.
choices.content: In 1950, about 400,000 lions roamed Africa, but today fewer than 40,000 remain.

options.definition: ways to find and follow animals or people in nature
Maa·sai (mah-SY): group of people who live in East Africa
live·stock (LIVE-stahk): farm animals like cows and sheep
